attachments.title: Goodbye, American neoliberalism. A new era is here | Cornel West
attachments.text: Trump’s election was enabled by the policies that overlooked the plight of our most vulnerable citizens. We gird ourselves for a frightening future
attachments.fallback: the Guardian: Goodbye, American neoliberalism. A new era is here | Cornel West

text: i respect dr. west but i also do not find his brand of rock-throwing to be particularly helpful at the moment.  Just a week before the election he was on tv talking about how choosing trump or hillary was like cancer or AIDS.  I don't disagree with his critique of neoliberalism but I also don't find him or his brand particularly helpful.
for the record, i would rather have AIDS than cancer.
Yeah I think Dr. West is just one of the many approaches, sometimes I enjoy it sometimes theres a different approach needed.

attachments.title: The 'us and them' divide worked for Putin and it will work for Trump
attachments.text: We Russians have watched our president embrace anyone prepared to join his gang and do his bidding. Americans will see the same from their new president
attachments.fallback: the Guardian: The 'us and them' divide worked for Putin and it will work for Trump

text: we need to unite against a common enemy.  period.
I just found out that Trump's assigning Sarah Palin to his cabinet
i didn't think it could get worse
My mom told me that over the weekend :confused:

attachments.fallback: New York Post: Sarah Palin not being considered for any Trump cabinet positions

text: Oh my god please please please

Not a huge fan of Cornell West myself, but I think his point about the death of neoliberalism is a very interesting one. Echoes a lot of what Robert Reich talks about in his interview here <http://www.rollingstone.com/politics/features/robert-reichs-8-point-plan-for-a-new-democratic-party-w451713>, which TLDR calls for a populist progressive party

attachments.title: Robert Reich's 8-Point Plan for a New Democratic Party
attachments.text: Former Labor Secretary Robert Reich says the party must be rebuilt from the ground up, and he has some ideas about how that should be done.
attachments.fallback: Rolling Stone: Robert Reich's 8-Point Plan for a New Democratic Party

text: The interview is well worth a read and speaks to what I think is one of the more interesting consequences of this election. The momentary triumph of populism over neoliberalism. I’ve always had an uneasy relationship with neoliberalism. Growing up as a teen in the Bush years, I read a lot of radical economic books by the likes of Naomi Klein, John Perkins and more, talking about the problems of neoliberalism (IMF, World Bank, etc). As I grew up though and began to read more and more, I found (find?) understanding at a macroeconomic level what those policies were aiming for at a intellectual level and by extension, almost became a neoliberalist myself. This has been a great tension within myself for that last 8 years and it’s interesting to see that  it is a grand tension playing itself out on the global stage.
